channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Why Italy’s Insular Election Is More Important Than It Looks
item.media:description: Members of the far-right movement CasaPound holding torches during a demonstration in Milan last month.
item.description: Before Sunday’s vote, Italy’s campaign, self-obsessed as it has been, brought into focus the political forces that portend badly for the European Union.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: The Toys They Carried: Syrian Children Under Siege
item.media:description: Maya, 5, holds her dolls close as her family shelters in a basement in their Damascus suburb.
item.description: Children in the Damascus suburb of eastern Ghouta are finding ways to pass the time in cramped basement shelters. But they are not insulated from the war.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and HWAIDA SAAD
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Stung by U.S. Tariff Plan, Canada Takes a Deep Breath
item.media:description: The ArcelorMittal Dofasco steel plant in Hamilton, Ontario. Canada is the No. 1 exporter of steel and aluminum to the United States and is vulnerable to tariffs.
item.media:credit: Lucas Oleniuk/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, conscious of how much his country’s economy relies on the United States, remained calm and firm.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER and IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Militants Carry Out Deadly Attacks in Burkina Faso
item.media:description: Assaults on Friday in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso, left at least eight members of the security forces and eight attackers dead.
item.description: Assaults on a military headquarters and on the French Embassy left at least eight members of the security forces and eight attackers dead.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Europe Was Colder Than the North Pole This Week. How Could That Be?
item.media:description: A gondolier cleared snow this week in Venice.
item.description: Europe is being battered by unusually frigid conditions even as temperatures in the North Pole soar well above normal. Here's the connection, according to experts.
item.dc:creator: KENDRA PIERRE-LOUIS

item.title: Will Russia Meddle in Italy’s Election? It May Not Have To
item.media:description: Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy posing for photographers in a television studio in January. Mr. Berlusconi has sought to position himself as a bridge between the United States and Russia.
item.description: Even as evidence mounts that Moscow interfered in past votes in Italy and elsewhere, it still stands to win in almost any result in Sunday’s election.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Pristina Journal: Not the Worst Hotel in the World, Perhaps, but ‘the World Is Very Big’
item.media:description: The Grand Hotel in Pristina, Kosovo.
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.description: With 500 rooms, one guest, pigeons on the top floors and many cockroaches, the Grand Hotel in Kosovo reflects the travails of a new nation.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Seeking Asylum, an Escort Has a Tale of Trump and Russia to Offer
item.media:description: Anastasia Vashukevich, a Belarusian escort and blogger who also goes by the name Nastya Rybka, is in custody in Thailand.
item.description: A Belarusian model claims to have details about dealings involving the president and Russian officials — if only someone could get her out of detention in Thailand.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: She Stood Up to Duterte. Now She Faces Impeachment.
item.media:description: Chief Justice Maria Lourdes Sereno of the Philippines, the first woman to lead the country’s judiciary, is expected to be impeached next week. “This fight is much larger than myself,” she said.
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes for The New York Times
item.description: Supporters of Chief Justice Maria Lourdes Sereno, who is accused of concealing some of her income, say she is a thorn in the side of the authoritarian president.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Ethnic Clashes in Northeastern Congo Leave Dozens Dead, Officials Say
item.description: Fighting between Hema herders and Lendu farmers in the northeastern province of Ituri in the Democratic Republic of Congo have killed more than 40 people.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Analysis: Trump’s Steel Tariffs Raise Fears of a Damaging Trade War
item.media:description: A U.S. Steel plant in Clairton, Pa. Many economists worry that foreign retaliation against American tariffs on steel and aluminum imports could escalate.
item.description: A global tit-for-tat on trade could crimp economic growth, undermining the stimulative effects of President Trump’s deregulation push and his signature $1.5 trillion tax cut.
item.dc:creator: JIM TANKERSLEY

item.title: World’s Longest-Imprisoned Journalist Is Freed in Uzbekistan
item.description: After 19 years in prison in one of the most repressive states, Yusuf Ruzimuradov was released. He had been accused of sedition.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Tariffs, Michigan, Nor’easter: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Todd Spoth for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: China’s Biggest Deal Maker Spent Billions. Now the Bill Comes Due.
item.media:description: A Beijing high-rise bearing the HNA logo. The company racked up $90 billion in debt with big purchases and investments in names like Hilton Hotels, Deutsche Bank and Virgin Australia. A third of it is due this year.
item.description: As Beijing puts growing pressure on some of the country’s most ambitious companies, HNA rushes to sell assets to help pay back $90 billion in debt.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Hitting the Road in Quebec and Looking for Your Guidance: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Dan Bilefsky in the Plateau-Mount Royal neighborhood of Montreal.
item.description: Dan Bilefsky, who has returned to his Montreal birthplace to become part of the The New York Times’s Canada team, is taking a road trip to reacquaint himself with Quebec.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Putin Flaunted Five Powerful Weapons. Are They a Threat?
item.description: The animated videos show Russian warheads speeding toward Florida. Here's what we know about the weapons Vladimir V. Putin promised on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD and AINARA TIEFENTHÄLER

item.title: China Presses Its Internet Censorship Efforts Across the Globe
item.media:description: China is using its status as home to the world’s largest population of internet users to help get what it wants outside of its borders.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: Beijing is pushing past its digital borders to influence and control what people say online, as it enjoys growing sway in the technology world.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Saturday Profile: The 28-Year-Old Socialist Who Could End the Merkel Era
item.media:description: Kevin Kühnert, right, speaking at a campaign event in Berlin.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Kevin Kühnert has become the face of a grass-roots rebellion among the Social Democrats as they prepare to vote on a proposed governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Theresa May Says U.K. Has to Face ‘Hard Facts’ on Brexit
item.media:description: Britain’s Prime Minister Theresa May outlined her vision for Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union at Mansion House in London on Friday.
item.description: The British prime minister struck a note of realism, saying trade with the European Union would suffer in a withdrawal, but vowed to get on with it.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Boko Haram Militants Kill Aid Workers at Military Base in Nigeria
item.media:description: The bodies of three aid workers killed in a Boko Haram attack arrived at the airport in Maiduguri, Nigeria, on Friday.
item.description: At least 11 people died in the attack near a camp for displaced people in the northeastern state of Borno.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Is Questioned in 3rd Corruption Case in Israel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Tel Aviv last month. He has been trying to project a business-as-usual approach despite his mounting legal troubles.
item.description: The prime minister and his wife were interviewed by the police about graft allegations involving a telecommunications tycoon. Mr. Netanyahu has denied all wrongdoing.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle Invite Members of Public to Wedding Day
item.media:description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle in Edinburgh last month. Members of the public from across Britain and from various walks of life will be nominated to attend celebrations on their wedding day.
item.description: Kensington Palace said that the couple would welcome a total of 2,640 people from all walks of life to Windsor Castle in May to watch the arrival of the bride and groom.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Fire at Azerbaijan Drug Treatment Clinic Kills at Least 24
item.media:description: Firefighters at the drug rehabilitation center in Baku, Azerbaijan, that burned on Friday.
item.media:credit: Vugar Amrullayev/Rex, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The fire in the capital, Baku, broke out in an old wooden building and was caused by a short circuit, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Italy Braces for Fake News as Election Approaches
item.media:description: Matteo Renzi, the leader of Italy’s governing Democratic Party, has called on social media companies to police their platforms to avoid the spread of false information before the election on Sunday.
item.description: In the run-up Europe’s next major vote, we look at how misinformation has spread in other recent elections.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Venezuela Delays Presidential Vote, but Opposition Still Plans a Boycott
item.media:description: The representatives of some Venezuelan political parties, including Luis Romero, center, said they would take part in the presidential election, but the main opposition coalition said it would still boycott the vote.
item.description: The government said the election, originally scheduled for April 22, would be postponed until May 20.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Argentina’s Top Spy Accused in Brazil Corruption Case
item.media:description: Brazilian officials on Thursday accused Gustavo Arribas, Argentina’s intelligence chief, of being part of a money-laundering scheme.
item.description: The allegations against Gustavo Arribas represent the first time a senior official in President Mauricio Macri’s administration has been caught up in the wide-ranging investigation.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI and ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Carles Puigdemont Abandons Bid for Catalonia Presidency
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont at a news conference in Brussels in December. He has given up his campaign to be reappointed as Catalonia’s president.
item.description: The leader of the main separatist alliance in Catalonia has given up his campaign to be reappointed as the region’s president.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY and RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: China’s Parliament Is a Growing Billionaires’ Club
item.media:description: A Cartier boutique in Beijing. China added 210 billionaires over the past year, according to the Hurun Report, a research organization that tracks the wealthy in China.
item.description: The wealth of 153 of the richest members of the National People’s Congress and its advisory body rose to $650 billion last year — just below Switzerland’s annual economic output.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: Tariffs, Delta, Putin: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Poland and Israel in Tense Talks Over Law Likened to Holocaust Denial
item.media:description: Visitors wearing Israeli flags at the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial last month.
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.description: The Polish law makes it a crime to blame “the Polish nation” for the Holocaust and other Nazi crimes.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and JOANNA BERENDT
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: In Vatican Magazine Exposé, Nuns Reveal Their Economic Exploitation
item.media:description: Nuns at a Mass celebrated by Pope Francis with members of different religious orders in St. Peter’s Basilica at the Vatican last month.
item.description: Sisters are often relegated to unsung, and underpaid, roles in a male-centric church that does not recognize their talents or capabilities, according to nuns interviewed by a women’s magazine.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Prince William Will Go to Israel, in First Official Visit by a British Royal
item.media:description: Prince William, second in line to the British throne, will visit Israel, Jordan and the Palestinian territories in the occupied West Bank this summer.
item.description: Nearly 70 years after the British Mandate ended, Prince William will make an official visit to the area, ending what many Israelis saw as a royal snub.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Putin Vows to Lift Russia’s Struggling Middle Class
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s speech on the state of the nation resonated as an acknowledgement that international sanctions continue to hurt ordinary Russians.
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin used his annual address to lay out a plan to reduce poverty and revive middle class fortunes.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Confined on His Last Trip to Saudi Arabia, Lebanon’s Leader Returns on Better Terms
item.media:description: In a picture provided by the Saudi Royal Palace, King Salman, right, received Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, on Wednesday.
item.description: The Saudi news media showed Prime Minister Saad Hariri smiling and conferring with King Salman. There was no mention of the unpleasantness of the previous visit.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: South Korea Tells U.S. It Will Send Envoy to North Korea
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea notified President Trump on Thursday that his government would send an envoy to North Korea to help arrange talks between the North and the United States.
item.description: President Moon Jae-in informed President Trump that South Korea would send a special envoy to the North to help arrange talks with Washington.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Facebook to End News Feed Experiment in 6 Countries That Magnified Fake News
item.media:description: A booth at Facebook’s annual F8 developer conference in San Jose, Calif. The social network is stopping the experiment known as Explore, which separates news publishers from its main site.
item.description: The social network is ending Explore, an experiment in countries like Bolivia and Cambodia, where it had separated news and other publishers from its main site.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL

item.title: Q Is for Queuing: Minting British Traditions With New 10-Pence Coins
item.media:description: The Royal Mint in Britain will release a new set of 10-pence coins this month, each devoted to a different British tradition or icon. B is for “Bond ... James Bond.”
item.description: Tea, an English breakfast and ice cream, along with icons from the obscure to the most famous, appear on coins designed for collectors and the public.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Germany Says Hackers Infiltrated Main Government Network
item.media:description: Hackers penetrated a German government system that is used by the chancellor’s office, ministries and the Parliament, above.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Officials said the attack was narrowly targeted, but they would not comment on reports of Russian involvement.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: After U.S.-Based Reporters Exposed Abuses, China Seized Their Relatives
item.media:description: Shohret Hoshur is one of at least five reporters for Radio Free Asia whose family members are being held in China or have gone missing, the Washington-based news agency said.
item.description: The Radio Free Asia journalists, at least three of whom are American citizens, have reported on China’s crackdown on ethnic Uighurs in the Xinjiang region.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to Mexico to Quit Amid Tense Relations Under Trump
item.media:description: Roberta S. Jacobson, center, the United States ambassador to Mexico, during a ceremony last month to break ground for the new American Embassy in Mexico City.
item.description: Roberta S. Jacobson is one of the most experienced Latin America experts in the State Department, having spent most of her 31-year tenure focused on the region.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Rites of Passage: Hi Hi Good Morning Hi I Love You It’s Me
item.media:description: Illustration by Tracy Ma/The New York Times
item.description: WhatsApp connects families around the world in amazing ways, and also is a complete nightmare.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Trilobites: They’re Hosting Parasitic Worms in Their Bodies to Help Treat a Neglected Disease
item.media:description: Schistosoma mansoni parasites, the cause of the disease bilharzia, or schistosomiasis. The brown worm is an adult male and the green one is female.
item.description: 17 healthy volunteers were paid to help prove a method of testing vaccines for schistosomiasis, which can be lethal, but some researchers are conflicted about the trial.
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MURPHY

item.title: Heaviest Snow in Decades Batters U.K., Ireland and the Continent
item.media:description: Lake Pecs, in central Hungary, froze over.
item.description: A rare Siberian chill is hitting Europe with unusually cold, snowy and windy conditions. Britain warned of a “risk to life,” and the country faces a natural gas shortage.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Putin’s ‘Invincible’ Missile Is Aimed at U.S. Vulnerabilities
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin offered Russians a rosy picture of future prosperity and military might in his annual speech, delivered on Thursday in Moscow.
item.description: Russians had wondered before Mr. Putin’s speech what he planned for his last term, and they got an answer: Russia will be a superpower again.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: News Analysis: Pakistan’s Shields Suddenly Step Aside, Placing It on Terrorism Listing
item.media:description: Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the founder of Lashkar-e-Taiba, the group suspected of being behind the deadly 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India, in Lahore, Pakistan, after a court ordered his release from house arrest. Pakistan is accused of not doing enough to stop groups that sponsor terrorism.
item.description: The acceptance by China and Saudi Arabia of the U.S. effort to list Pakistan as too lax on terrorism financing is prompting worry, and debate, in Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: MARIA ABI-HABIB and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: 5 Places: Five Places to Go in Nashville
item.media:description: Andrew Hannigan prepares cocktails at Bastion bar and restaurant in Nashville's Wedgewood-Houston neighborhood.
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.description: Nashville’s Wedgewood-Houston neighborhood was long a run-down part of town. After creative types moved into the area, trendy restaurants, galleries, distilleries and other business have followed.
item.dc:creator: SHIVANI VORA
